newsitem.title: CANADA: Southern buys stake in Asian utility for $2.7 billion.
newsitem.headline: Southern buys stake in Asian utility for $2.7 billion.

text.p: Southern Co. said Wednesday its Southern Electric International unit has agreed to purchase a majority interest in Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd. in a deal worth $2.7 billion.
Consolidated Electric, one of Asia's largest independent power producers, is now 60.4 percent owned by Hong Kong-based Hopewell Holdings Ltd.

"Under the agreement, CEPA (Consolidated Electric) shareholders will receive $2.1 billion from Southern and $600 million in dividends for 80 percent of the company. Hopewell will become the largest minority shareholder of CEPA," Southern said.
Company officials were not immediately available to explain how this transaction would be carried out.

"Combining the assets of Southern Electric International and CEPA will create one of the world's largest independent power producers, supplying electricity to the heart of Asia -- including three of the world's most populated countries -- as well as Europe, North America and South America," said Southern Chief Executive Officer A.W. Dahlberg.
Consolidated Electric Asia owns and operates electric power generating plants in China and the Philippines with projects under development in Pakistan and Indonesia.
The company was established in 1993 as a holding company for Hopewell's electric power projects.
Atlanta-based Southern said the transaction was subject to approvals by the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong and CEPA shareholders.

Southern, the largest producer of electricity in the United States, is the parent of five Southeast electric utilities: Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power and Savannah Electric. Southern stock was off 62.5 cents at $21.875 on the New York Stock Exchange in afternoon trading.
